docs.text: NRCAn Instruments General These instruments have been deployed at NEPTUNE at various sites, see table below. Their device names in Oceans 3.0 are NRCan Bottom Pressure Recorder XX where XX is the logger ID. There are two different NRCan BPR types: Type 1 or ‘TP’, which include a Paroscientific pressure sensor with only a pressure channel and a platinum resistance thermometer or thermistor Type 2 or ‘TTP’, which include a Paroscientific pressure sensor with both pressure and temperature channels and a platinum resistance thermometer or thermistor Some ‘TTP’ BPRs are referred as ‘TTP-minusT’, as they do not contain a platinum thermistor sensor These BPRs use Paroscientific pressure sensors model 8B4000-1 or 8B4000-2. Model naming breakdown: 8B: Series 8B "High Pressure Absolute Depth Sensors" 4000: max depth in metres -1: single output, pressure only -2: pressure and temperature output Are Paroscientific model 4000KR also used? I could not find records in Jira of this model being used. Sensor Naming Conventions (e.g., what does SCVIPBPR mean?) Sensors are dependent on the type of BPR, as follows. NRCan Sensor Naming Scheme in Oceans3.0: DART Pressure Residual: contains raw pressure readings that have their tidal portion removed to leave only noise and pressure spikes. Housing Temperature: corresponds to the readings from the platinum sensor inside the housing. However, it is tightly coupled with the water temperature even though it is not in-situ. Instrument Clock: measures the BPR internal clock. P-Sensor Temperature: Reported only for TTP type. It corresponds to the temperature measurements from the Paroscientific pressure sensor. These readings are used to calibrate the pressure measurements which are reported by the Seafloor Pressure sensor. Seafloor Pressure: readings are dependent on the BPR type as follows: For TP type, pressure values are calibrated using the Housing Temperature readings which influence (falsify) the Pressure readings for short-term events due to the Housing Temperature being noise sensitive to small environmental changes. For TTP and TTP-minusT types, pressure values are calibrated using the Paroscientific internal temperature readings, which are less noise sensitive to small environmental changes compared to those of the TP type. Uncompensated Seafloor Pressure: these sensors are only present in the TP type, as TTP devices have internal temperature sensors to compensate/calibrate the pressure readings, which have the same level of sensitivity as the pressure sensors and do not falsify the readings. For the TP type, these sensor readings enable a better evaluation of these short-term events, as they are not influenced by the Housing Temperature calibration.

docs.text: Purpose: To explain the "why" behind the concepts. E-01: Principles of Seafloor Geodesy What are we measuring and why? (Tectonic strain, slow slip, tsunamis). E-02: Sources of "Noise" in Pressure Data Why do sensors drift? (Instrumental vs. environmental). What are the non-tectonic signals? (Tides, ocean loading, seasonal cycles, tsunamis). E-03: The CORK Observatory What is a CORK and how does it work? What's the difference between formation pressure and hydrostatic pressure? E-04: The Diátaxis Framework A link to the official Diátaxis site. Explains why the documentation is structured this way. Regarding NOAA and their use of our pressure sensors, Martin’s comment in GChat: Since they seem to use pressure across the board, I do not think we need to inform them immediately, as long as the data flow is not interrupted. We should make a note to create some documentation about the difference between the two sensors, and when each one is better to use. We should also check it NOAA is using the best sensors that we have at the moment. Disclaimer should be added for missing DART Pressure Residual 3 hours of data

docs.text: Purpose: The technical "encyclopedia" of every sensor. This is where "quirks" live. R-01: Instrument: Bottom Pressure Recorders (BPRs) Models in Use (e.g., Paroscientific 8B4000) Ocean Networks Canada has deployed various BPR models throughout time. The following models have been used: NRCan BPRs These instruments have been deployed at NEPTUNE at various sites, see table below. Their device names in Oceans 3.0 are NRCan Bottom Pressure Recorder XX where XX is the logger ID. There are two different NRCan BPR types: Type 1 or ‘TP’, which include a Paroscientific pressure sensor with only a pressure channel and a platinum resistance thermometer or thermistor Type 2 or ‘TTP’, which include a Paroscientific pressure sensor with both pressure and temperature channels and a platinum resistance thermometer or thermistor Some ‘TTP’ BPRs are referred as ‘TTP-minusT’, as they do not contain a platinum thermistor sensor These BPRs use Paroscientific pressure sensors model 8B4000-1 or 8B4000-2. Model naming breakdown: 8B: Series 8B "High Pressure Absolute Depth Sensors" 4000: max depth in metres -1: single output, pressure only -2: pressure and temperature output Are Paroscientific model 4000KR also used? I could not find records in Jira of this model being used. RBR Quartz3 BPR These instruments have been deployed at NEPTUNE at various sites, see table below. These instruments contain a Paroscientific Digiquartz® pressure sensor (model 46K-101, 46K-313, 46KR-101) and an internal temperature sensor. Paroscientific Pressure Sensor Models 8B4000-2, 8CB4000-I, 8DP130-I, 8DP200-I were part of NRCan’s Delta Dynamics Laboratory (DDL) and Seismic Liquefaction In-situ Penetrometer (SLIP) platforms within VENUS in the Strait of Georgia. Sensor Naming Conventions (e.g., what does SCVIPBPR mean?) Sensors are dependent on the type of BPR, as follows. NRCan BPRs: DART Pressure Residual: contains raw pressure readings that have their tidal portion removed to leave only noise and pressure spikes. Housing Temperature: corresponds to the readings from the platinum sensor inside the housing. However, it is tightly coupled with the water temperature even though it is not in-situ. Instrument Clock: measures the BPR internal clock. P-Sensor Temperature: Reported only for TTP type. It corresponds to the temperature measurements from the Paroscientific pressure sensor. These readings are used to calibrate the pressure measurements which are reported by the Seafloor Pressure sensor. Seafloor Pressure: readings are dependent on the BPR type as follows: For TP type, pressure values are calibrated using the Housing Temperature readings which influence (falsify) the Pressure readings for short-term events due to the Housing Temperature being noise sensitive to small environmental changes. For TTP and TTP-minusT types, pressure values are calibrated using the Paroscientific internal temperature readings, which are less noise sensitive to small environmental changes compared to those of the TP type. Uncompensated Seafloor Pressure: these sensors are only present in the TP type, as TTP devices have internal temperature sensors to compensate/calibrate the pressure readings, which have the same level of sensitivity as the pressure sensors and do not falsify the readings. For the TP type, these sensor readings enable a better evaluation of these short-term events, as they are not influenced by the Housing Temperature calibration. RBR Quartz3 BPRs: DART Pressure Residual: same as the above. Temperature: readings from the internal temperature sensor. Instrument Clock: measures the BPR internal clock. P-Sensor Temperature: corresponds to the temperature measurements from the Paroscientific pressure sensor. These readings are used to calibrate the pressure measurements which are reported by the Seafloor Pressure sensor. Seafloor Pressure: pressure readings are calibrated using the Paroscientific internal temperature readings Paroscientific Pressure Sensor: Temperature: corresponds to the temperature measurements from Most of the known issues added for CORK (below) also apply to NRCan BPRs, do we want to use the same section for both? Typical drift rates For NRCan BPRs: To be added, cannot find any info on drift based on https://docs.oceannetworks.ca/share/page/site/operations-docs/folder-details?nodeRef=workspace://SpacesStore/36dd0f5c-dc4b-4d5f-bb66-25e2183bfafe For RBR Quartz3 BPRs, typical drift rate is ±60 seconds/year, according to manufacturer documentation. For Paroscientific Pressure sensors, drift rate is to be found, no info in Alfresco. Documented tares (jumps) or failures What do we want to add here? Historical failures of BPRs at NEPTUNE? Calibration coefficients (if available) Calibration coefficients for all instruments are part of calibration sheets provided by the manufacturer (Paroscientific, RBR). These coefficients are used in Oceans 3.0 sensor calibration formulas in the following way: NRCan BPR Housing Temperature: Formula is ($XXXX * SLOPE) + INTERCEPT where XXXX is the Housing Temperature sensorID, SLOPE and INTERCEPT values depend on the SN of the platinum sensor NRCan BPR P-Sensor Temperature (only on TTP type): Formula is BPRGaugeTemperature($TTTT, U0, Y1, Y2,C1, C2, C3, D1, T1,T2, T3, T4,2) where TTTT is the P-sensor Temperature sensorID, U0, Y1,Y2,Y3, C1, C2, C3, D1, T1,T2, T3, T4 are Paroscientific calibration coefficients, the last input is always 2 (it indicates that it is a TTP device) NRCan BPR Seafloor Pressure (TP and TTP) and Uncompensated Seafloor Pressure (TP only): Formulas are as follows depending on the BPR type CorkPressureTP(($TTTT* SLOPE) + INTERCEPT, $XXXX, 0, 0, 0, C1, C2, C3, D1, T1,T2, T3, T4, 1) for Seafloor Pressure, where TT is the sensorID of the Housing Temperature sensor, and the SLOPE and INTERCEPT are the same as in the Housing Temperature calibration formula (see formula above) CorkPressureTP((TTTT, $XXXX, 0, 0, 0, C1, C2, C3, D1, T1,T2, T3, T4, 1) for Uncompensated Seafloor Pressure, where TTTT is an empirically obtained average temperature value at the deployment site (instead of the slope/intercept formula) - this is obtained from ONC’s Science team CorkPressureTTP($TTTT, $XXXX, U0, Y1, Y2, C1, C2, C3, D1, T1,T2, T3,T4, 2) for Seafloor Pressure TP type, where TTTT is the 'P-sensor Temperature' sensorID, XXXX is the sensorID of the pressure sensor for which the formula is being applied (e.g., either the Seafloor Pressure sensorID or Uncompensated Seafloor Pressure sensorID), C1, C2, C3, D1, T1,T2, T3, T4 are Paroscientific’s calibration coefficients, and U0,Y1,Y2,Y3 are additional Parsocientific’s calibration coefficients IF TTP, 0s otherwise. The last parameter is 2 for TTP, 0 or 1 for TP or none. RBR Quartz3 BPR P-Sensor Temperature: Formula is BPRTemperatureDouble($TTTT, U0, Y1, Y2, C1, C2, C3, D1, T1, T2, T3, T4, 3) where TTTT is the P-Sensor Temperature sensorID, and U0, Y1, Y2, C1, C2, C3, D1, T1, T2, T3, T4 are Paroscientific’s calibration coefficients. However if RBR also provides a calibration certificate where they revise parameter values, then those are used instead. The last input is always 3 to account for the input being in picoseconds. RBR Quartz3 BPR Seafloor Pressure: Formula is BPRPressureDouble($TTTT, $XXXX, U0, Y1, Y2, C1, C2, C3, D1, T1, T2, T3, T4, 3) where TTTT is the P-sensor Temperature sensorID, XXXX is the sensorID of the Seafloor Pressure sensor for which the formula is being applied, U0, Y1, Y2, C1, C2, C3, D1, T1, T2, T3, T4 are obtained Paroscientific’s calibration coefficients. However if RBR also provides a calibration certificate where they revise parameter values, then those are used instead. The last parameter is always 3 to account for the input being in picoseconds DART Pressure Residual: Formula is DARTDetider(SeafloorPressureSensorID, $SeafloorPressureSensorID, $date) where SeafloorPressureSensorID is the Sensor ID of the 'Seafloor Pressure' sensor of the BPR, $SeafloorPressureSensorID are the readings of the 'Seafloor Pressure ' sensor of the BPR and $date is the 'Reading date'. Example of a Paroscientific calibration sheet: R-02: Instrument: CORKs (Circulation Obviation Retrofit Kits) Installation Overview The Circulation Obviation Retrofit Kit (CORK) is a type of long-term subseafloor hydrogeological observatory. The primary function of a CORK is to seal the top of a deep-sea borehole to prevent the circulation (obviation) of ocean bottom water into or out of the subseafloor formation. This seal allows scientists to obtain in-situ (on-site) measurements of temperature and pressure within the isolated formation, and to collect borehole fluid samples over long periods of time. This data is crucial for studying subseafloor hydrology, fluid flow, and pressure changes in zones like the Cascadia Subduction Zone. Ocean Networks Canada utilizes and maintains CORK observatories at the following sites: ClayoquotSlope_CORK-1364A_2010-09 , CascadiaBasin_CORK-1026B_2007-09 , ClayoquotSlope_CORK-1364A_2010-09 . The CORK system location and system type for these observatories is detailed below. Advanced CORK (ACORK) is a multi-Level Pressure/Temperature where Hydraulic tubing runs from the multiple internal screens (installed with the casing) to a manifold on the CORK head. ONC connects real-time pressure sensors and thermistor cables to this manifold. ODP CORK instrumentation includes a long cable containing pressure sensors and thermistors deployed via wireline down the central bore of the CORK and into the deep hole. The logger/data recovery unit is seated in the CORK head. Borehole ID Location/Geology CORK System Type U1364A Clayoquot Slope Accretionary Prism (Sediment) ACORK (Advanced CORK) 1026B, 1027C, 1024C Cascadia Basin (Basement/Sediment) ODP CORK (Upgraded) 1026B, 1027C, 1024 During Ocean Drilling Program (ODP) Leg 168, Hole 1027C was drilled to 632 meters below seafloor (mbsf), 2.2 km east of Hole 1026C, where sediment thickness is 575 m above a buried basement low as shown below. This figure shows regional bathymetry (Davis, Fisher, Firth, et al., 1997) showing locations of ODP and IODP drill sites. Contour interval is 10 m. Solid circle is Hole 1027C; open circles are other holes drilled during earlier expeditions (blue) or Expedition 327 (black). Gold contours show locations of basement exposure on Baby Bare, Mama Bare, and Papa Bare outcrops. The upper part of the hole was cased through sediments and the uppermost basement, with 54 m of open hole. The open interval near the base of Hole 1027C comprises a diabase sill, intercalated sediments, and basalt breccia overlying 26 m of extrusive volcanic rocks (Shipboard Scientific Party, 1997). A subseafloor borehole observatory (“CORK”) that included a data logger, pressure sensors, thermistors at multiple depths, and a fluid sampler was installed in Hole 1027C during Leg 168. Observatory instruments were retrieved in 1999, and the pressure logging system was replaced. The CORK in Hole 1027C was scheduled to be replaced during Integrated Ocean Drilling Program (IODP) Expedition 301, but problems setting the CORK in Hole U1301B and a lack of time and materials prevented the completion of any Hole 1027C operations during that expedition. Hole 1027C was fully sealed and continued to record formation pressure before, during, and after Expedition 301. The pressure record from this hole provided evidence of a long-term, cross-hole response to drilling and other operations in Hole U1301B as well as a subsequent period of fluid flow down into Hole U1301B, which was not completely sealed (Fisher et al., 2008; Davis et al., 2010). Researchers visited Hole 1027C with DSRV Alvin during summer 2009 to prepare the CORK for replacement by retrieving a battery pack and communications package from the remotely operated vehicle (ROV) platform and removing an underwater electrical connector from the top of the wellhead. Unfortunately, the connector was corroded in place and could not be removed, but the ROV platform was cleared for CORK retrieval operations. The primary scientific objectives at Site 1027 during Expedition 327 were to recover the existing CORK in Hole 1027C, core and deepen the hole by \~40–50 m, run hydrologic tests of the open hole, and deploy a new multilevel CORK for monitoring, sampling, and associated experiments. These operations could not be completed because the CORK in Hole 1027C could not be unlatched from the reentry cone and casing system. Thus, the old observatory remains in place, and additional servicing will be attempted during future dive operations to replace the pressure logging system with modern instrumentation. For more details, see https://publications.iodp.org/proceedings/327/105/105_f1.htm U1364A The Clayoquot Slope IODP (Integrated Ocean Discovery Program) borehole observatory CORK U1364A is located in the Vancouver Margin of the northern Cascadia Subduction Zone, \~20km landward of the accretionary prism toe. The CORK (Circulation Obviation Retrofit Kit) observatory was installed in 2010 during IODP Expedition 328 (Davis & Malone, 2010; Davis & Heesemann, 2011). The location of this ACORK observatory is shown below. This figure shows borehole locations from ODP Leg 146 (889A-C), Expedition 311 (U1327A, U1327B, and U1328A), Expedition 341S (U1416A), and Expedition 328 (U1364A) on multibeam bathymetric data from Paull et al. (2015) . Also shown is approximate position of the ONC Clayoquot Slope node. Arrowheads on PGC 89-08 and IL35 seismic lines. Triangles show locations of mapped seafloor formation fluid or gas seeps from Scherwath et al. (2019) . Site U1416A is not discussed in this paper, but it is shown because it is the location of a SCIMPI (Simple Cabled Instrument to Measure Parameters In Situ) observatory also intended to monitor temperatures down to BSR depths ( Expedition 341S Scientists and Engineers, 2013 ; Lado-Insua et al., 2013 ). Sensor Naming Conventions Seafloor Pressure Seafloor Temperature Borehole Pressure(s) Borehole Temperature(s) Housing Temperature Thermistors and platinum sensors are two different components to measure temperature. Thermistors are semiconductors, they have great sensitivity (a lot of change of resistance per degree), but have complicated calibration formulas and are less stable over the long term. That is why we moved from thermistors to platinum sensors as the sensitivity (with a "new" electronics board) was plenty good. Platinum sensors are used in CTDs. I think the CORK 1026B logger is the only legacy one with a thermistor. All newer instruments should have platinum sensors. No need to change the formulas. The results of the calibration should make it very clear if you have things mixed up. They would just not be reasonable temperatures. Deployment History & Sensor Depth (mbsf) Site Name Borehole ID DeviceID Depth (mbsf) Deployment Date Comments CascadiaBasin_CORK-1026B_2007-09 1026B 21301 200 2009-09-01 https://publications.iodp.org/proceedings/327/107/107_6.htm ClayoquotSlope_CORK-1364A_2010-09 1364A 23181 300 2010-09-17 https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/earth-science/articles/10.3389/feart.2020.568566/full CascadiaBasin_CORK-1027C 1027C 23150 632 2011-07-11 to 2018-05-19 And 2018-06-24 to present https://publications.iodp.org/proceedings/327/105/105_.htm CascadiaBasin_AutonomousCORK-1024C_2024-06 1024C 86472 ?? 2024-06-08 Known Issues & Characteristics The CORK observatories, particularly those in the Ocean Networks Canada (ONC) network, are designed for extreme longevity and high-precision measurements. However, like any sophisticated deep-sea system, they face a number of challenges related to the harsh operating environment. Sensor drift, biofouling, and calibration issues are among the most common problems for CORKs and all long-term cabled deep-sea observatories detailed below: Sensor Drift and Calibration Issues This is the most critical issue affecting data quality for the high-precision pressure and temperature sensors used in CORKs. A. Pressure and Temperature Sensor Drift The Problem: Sensor drift is a slow, gradual change in a sensor's baseline reading over time, causing it to report values that deviate from the true measurement. In CORKs, this is often seen in the high-resolution quartz crystal pressure sensors. Causes: Natural degradation of electronic components, material fatigue under extreme pressure (deep-sea environment), and exposure to the corrosive seawater environment or subseafloor fluids. Temperature fluctuations on the seafloor can also affect sensor electronics. The Impact: Since CORKs are looking for extremely small, time-dependent signals (like microbar pressure changes from plate strain or Slow Slip Events), even a slow drift of the sensor can mask or mimic the tiny geological signals being studied. B. Calibration Challenges The Problem: Sensors must be calibrated before and after deployment to quantify the drift. However, deep-sea calibration is difficult. Once a sensor is deployed in the CORK, its high-pressure, long-term performance can only be truly verified when it is recovered (usually years later). ONC's Mitigation: Redundancy: CORKs often have multiple, co-located sensors (e.g., pressure transducers) to cross-check readings and identify which sensor is drifting. External References (Hydrostatic Head): Scientists use the known density of the fluid column (seawater or borehole fluid) above the sensor to provide a hydrostatic reference point. Routine Servicing: ONC schedules regular (often annual) maintenance cruises using ROVs to recover the data logger/instrument string. The sensors are then returned to a lab for post-deployment calibration to accurately characterize and correct for any drift in the recorded data. ### 2. Biofouling Biofouling is the accumulation of marine organisms (microbes, barnacles, tube worms, etc.) on submerged surfaces.While the CORK sensors are deep, biofouling is still a concern, especially for certain components. The Problem in CORKs: Fluid Samplers: Biofilms can clog the small orifices and filters of the osmotic fluid samplers, preventing or restricting the collection of subseafloor fluid samples. Chemical Sensors: While CORKs primarily measure P and T, any specialized chemical sensors (e.g., for $\text{H}_2\text{S}$ or $\text{CH}_4$) placed on the CORK head for fluid sampling are highly susceptible. Biofouling can cover the sensing element or alter the local chemical environment, leading to a negative or positive measurement drift. ROV Couplers/Mates: Macro-fouling (larger organisms) on the CORK head can physically obstruct the connectors and tools used by the ROV for connecting cables, downloading data, or performing sampling. R-03: Instrument: APTs (Ambient Pressure Transducers) (Details TBD - how are these different from BPRs? Are they part of CORKs?) Purpose & Typical Applications Sensor Naming Conventions Deployment History R-04: Instrument: Self-Calibrating Recorders (Sonarydne Fetch AZA, RBR BPR zero) Models in Use: Sonardyne Fetch 8306-9926, RBR Quartz3 BPR zero Sonardyne Fetch 8306-9925 deviceid siteid sitename devicename devicetypeid 64120 1210049 UpperSlope_AZA_Fetch_2021-08 Sonardyne Fetch 8306-9926 SN 329742-001 376 RBR Quartz3 BPR zero deviceid sitedeviceid siteid sitename devicename devicetypeid 65960 1210053 1015540 UpperSlope_BPR_2021-08 RBR Quartz3 BPR zero SN 207223 461 67660 1210022 1024100 Clayoquot_Deformation_Front_East-2021-08 RBR Quartz3 BPR zero SN 207600 461 67660 1213669 1033072 Clayoquot_Deformation_Front_Middle-2023-07 RBR Quartz3 BPR zero SN 207600 461 67680 1210025 1024080 Clayoquot_Deformation_Front_Middle-2021-08 RBR Quartz3 BPR zero SN 207601 461 67680 1214263 1034772 MEF_South_BPR_2023-09 RBR Quartz3 BPR zero SN 207601 461 Principle of Operation (How the self-calibration works) Sonarydyne Fetch AZA The Sonardyne Fetch AZA (Ambient-Zero-Ambient) self-calibration mechanism is designed to eliminate drift in a high-accuracy, long-term seabed pressure sensor. This allows the instrument to maintain exceptionally high accuracy (centimetric-scale pressure measurements) for deployments up to 10 years or more. The core of the system involves three key pressure sensors, a small pump, and two valves, all contained within the instrument's protective sphere. The calibration cycle, performed periodically (e.g., initially frequent and then slowing down to a pre-programmed rate), consists of three main stages, which gives the system its name: Ambient (A): This is the normal operating state. The ambient (high pressure) sensor and the transfer (primary) sensor are both exposed to the external ambient seawater pressure at the seabed. The low-range zero reference sensor is sealed off. The transfer sensor continuously measures the ambient pressure. Zero (Z): The calibration phase. The ambient valve is closed, isolating the transfer sensor from the external seawater pressure. A small pump is activated to withdraw a piston, reducing the pressure in the internal chamber until it is near zero (near atmospheric pressure). The low-pressure valve is then opened, connecting the transfer sensor to the highly accurate, low-range zero reference sensor. Since the pressure is now near zero, the transfer sensor's reading (which would typically be several hundred bar) can be compared directly to the zero reference sensor's reading (only a few bar). The zero reference sensor is highly accurate at this low range because it is never subjected to high ambient pressure. This comparison allows the system to accurately measure the bias (drift) that has accumulated in the high-range transfer sensor. Ambient (A): Returning to normal logging. The low-pressure valve is closed, sealing off the zero reference sensor again to protect it. The pump piston is extended, returning the internal manifold pressure back up to the ambient seabed pressure. The ambient valve is opened, re-exposing the transfer sensor to the external seawater pressure. The instrument is now back in its normal logging mode, and the measured bias from the Zero stage is used in post-processing to correct all the pressure data logged by the transfer sensor since the last calibration cycle, effectively eliminating the sensor drift. More details can be found here . How to interpret the calibration data/coefficients. R-05: Data Products Official ONC-derived data products (e.g., "Tidally-Averaged Pressure"). Processing steps used to create them.

docs.text: These instruments have been deployed at NEPTUNE at various sites, see table below. Their device names in Oceans 3.0 are NRCan Bottom Pressure Recorder XX where XX is the logger ID. There are two different NRCan BPR types: Type 1 or ‘TP’, which include a Paroscientific pressure sensor with only a pressure channel and a platinum resistance thermometer or thermistor Type 2 or ‘TTP’, which include a Paroscientific pressure sensor with both pressure and temperature channels and a platinum resistance thermometer or thermistor Some ‘TTP’ BPRs are referred as ‘TTP-minusT’, as they do not contain a platinum thermistor sensor These BPRs use Paroscientific pressure sensors model 8B4000-1 or 8B4000-2. Model naming breakdown: 8B: Series 8B "High Pressure Absolute Depth Sensors" 4000: max depth in metres -1: single output, pressure only -2: pressure and temperature output Are Paroscientific model 4000KR also used? I could not find records in Jira of this model being used.
docs.title: NRCan BPRs

docs.text: These instruments have been deployed at NEPTUNE at various sites, see table below. These instruments contain a Paroscientific Digiquartz® pressure sensor (model 46K-101, 46K-313, 46KR-101) and an internal temperature sensor.

docs.text: Models 8B4000-2, 8CB4000-I, 8DP130-I, 8DP200-I were part of NRCan’s Delta Dynamics Laboratory (DDL) and Seismic Liquefaction In-situ Penetrometer (SLIP) platforms within VENUS in the Strait of Georgia.
docs.title: Paroscientific Pressure Sensor

docs.text: Sensors are dependent on the type of BPR, as follows. NRCan BPRs: DART Pressure Residual: contains raw pressure readings that have their tidal portion removed to leave only noise and pressure spikes. Housing Temperature: corresponds to the readings from the platinum sensor inside the housing. However, it is tightly coupled with the water temperature even though it is not in-situ. Instrument Clock: measures the BPR internal clock. P-Sensor Temperature: Reported only for TTP type. It corresponds to the temperature measurements from the Paroscientific pressure sensor. These readings are used to calibrate the pressure measurements which are reported by the Seafloor Pressure sensor. Seafloor Pressure: readings are dependent on the BPR type as follows: For TP type, pressure values are calibrated using the Housing Temperature readings which influence (falsify) the Pressure readings for short-term events due to the Housing Temperature being noise sensitive to small environmental changes. For TTP and TTP-minusT types, pressure values are calibrated using the Paroscientific internal temperature readings, which are less noise sensitive to small environmental changes compared to those of the TP type. Uncompensated Seafloor Pressure: these sensors are only present in the TP type, as TTP devices have internal temperature sensors to compensate/calibrate the pressure readings, which have the same level of sensitivity as the pressure sensors and do not falsify the readings. For the TP type, these sensor readings enable a better evaluation of these short-term events, as they are not influenced by the Housing Temperature calibration. RBR Quartz3 BPRs: DART Pressure Residual: same as the above. Temperature: readings from the internal temperature sensor. Instrument Clock: measures the BPR internal clock. P-Sensor Temperature: corresponds to the temperature measurements from the Paroscientific pressure sensor. These readings are used to calibrate the pressure measurements which are reported by the Seafloor Pressure sensor. Seafloor Pressure: pressure readings are calibrated using the Paroscientific internal temperature readings Paroscientific Pressure Sensor: Temperature: corresponds to the temperature measurements from the pressure sensor Pressure: corresponds to the pressure readings calibrated using the internal temperature readings

docs.text: The Clayoquot Slope IODP (Integrated Ocean Discovery Program) borehole observatory CORK U1364A is located in the Vancouver Margin of the northern Cascadia Subduction Zone, \~20km landward of the accretionary prism toe. The CORK (Circulation Obviation Retrofit Kit) observatory was installed in 2010 during IODP Expedition 328 (Davis & Malone, 2010; Davis & Heesemann, 2011). The location of this ACORK observatory is shown below. This figure shows borehole locations from ODP Leg 146 (889A-C), Expedition 311 (U1327A, U1327B, and U1328A), Expedition 341S (U1416A), and Expedition 328 (U1364A) on multibeam bathymetric data from Paull et al. (2015) . Also shown is approximate position of the ONC Clayoquot Slope node. Arrowheads on PGC 89-08 and IL35 seismic lines. Triangles show locations of mapped seafloor formation fluid or gas seeps from Scherwath et al. (2019) . Site U1416A is not discussed in this paper, but it is shown because it is the location of a SCIMPI (Simple Cabled Instrument to Measure Parameters In Situ) observatory also intended to monitor temperatures down to BSR depths ( Expedition 341S Scientists and Engineers, 2013 ; Lado-Insua et al., 2013 ).
docs.title: U1364A

docs.text: Seafloor Pressure Seafloor Temperature Borehole Pressure(s) Borehole Temperature(s) Housing Temperature Thermistors and platinum sensors are two different components to measure temperature. Thermistors are semiconductors, they have great sensitivity (a lot of change of resistance per degree), but have complicated calibration formulas and are less stable over the long term. That is why we moved from thermistors to platinum sensors as the sensitivity (with a "new" electronics board) was plenty good. Platinum sensors are used in CTDs. I think the CORK 1026B logger is the only legacy one with a thermistor. All newer instruments should have platinum sensors. No need to change the formulas. The results of the calibration should make it very clear if you have things mixed up. They would just not be reasonable temperatures.

docs.text: The CORK observatories, particularly those in the Ocean Networks Canada (ONC) network, are designed for extreme longevity and high-precision measurements. However, like any sophisticated deep-sea system, they face a number of challenges related to the harsh operating environment. Sensor drift, biofouling, and calibration issues are among the most common problems for CORKs and all long-term cabled deep-sea observatories detailed below:
docs.title: Known Issues & Characteristics

docs.text: This is the most critical issue affecting data quality for the high-precision pressure and temperature sensors used in CORKs.
docs.title: Sensor Drift and Calibration Issues

docs.text: The Problem: Sensor drift is a slow, gradual change in a sensor's baseline reading over time, causing it to report values that deviate from the true measurement. In CORKs, this is often seen in the high-resolution quartz crystal pressure sensors. Causes: Natural degradation of electronic components, material fatigue under extreme pressure (deep-sea environment), and exposure to the corrosive seawater environment or subseafloor fluids. Temperature fluctuations on the seafloor can also affect sensor electronics. The Impact: Since CORKs are looking for extremely small, time-dependent signals (like microbar pressure changes from plate strain or Slow Slip Events), even a slow drift of the sensor can mask or mimic the tiny geological signals being studied.
docs.title: A. Pressure and Temperature Sensor Drift

docs.text: The Problem: Sensors must be calibrated before and after deployment to quantify the drift. However, deep-sea calibration is difficult. Once a sensor is deployed in the CORK, its high-pressure, long-term performance can only be truly verified when it is recovered (usually years later). ONC's Mitigation: Redundancy: CORKs often have multiple, co-located sensors (e.g., pressure transducers) to cross-check readings and identify which sensor is drifting. External References (Hydrostatic Head): Scientists use the known density of the fluid column (seawater or borehole fluid) above the sensor to provide a hydrostatic reference point. Routine Servicing: ONC schedules regular (often annual) maintenance cruises using ROVs to recover the data logger/instrument string. The sensors are then returned to a lab for post-deployment calibration to accurately characterize and correct for any drift in the recorded data. ### 2. Biofouling Biofouling is the accumulation of marine organisms (microbes, barnacles, tube worms, etc.) on submerged surfaces.While the CORK sensors are deep, biofouling is still a concern, especially for certain components. The Problem in CORKs: Fluid Samplers: Biofilms can clog the small orifices and filters of the osmotic fluid samplers, preventing or restricting the collection of subseafloor fluid samples. Chemical Sensors: While CORKs primarily measure P and T, any specialized chemical sensors (e.g., for $\text{H}_2\text{S}$ or $\text{CH}_4$) placed on the CORK head for fluid sampling are highly susceptible. Biofouling can cover the sensing element or alter the local chemical environment, leading to a negative or positive measurement drift. ROV Couplers/Mates: Macro-fouling (larger organisms) on the CORK head can physically obstruct the connectors and tools used by the ROV for connecting cables, downloading data, or performing sampling.

docs.title: RBR Quartz3 BPR zero
Principle of Operation (How the self-calibration works)

docs.text: The Sonardyne Fetch AZA (Ambient-Zero-Ambient) self-calibration mechanism is designed to eliminate drift in a high-accuracy, long-term seabed pressure sensor. This allows the instrument to maintain exceptionally high accuracy (centimetric-scale pressure measurements) for deployments up to 10 years or more. The core of the system involves three key pressure sensors, a small pump, and two valves, all contained within the instrument's protective sphere. The calibration cycle, performed periodically (e.g., initially frequent and then slowing down to a pre-programmed rate), consists of three main stages, which gives the system its name: Ambient (A): This is the normal operating state. The ambient (high pressure) sensor and the transfer (primary) sensor are both exposed to the external ambient seawater pressure at the seabed. The low-range zero reference sensor is sealed off. The transfer sensor continuously measures the ambient pressure. Zero (Z): The calibration phase. The ambient valve is closed, isolating the transfer sensor from the external seawater pressure. A small pump is activated to withdraw a piston, reducing the pressure in the internal chamber until it is near zero (near atmospheric pressure). The low-pressure valve is then opened, connecting the transfer sensor to the highly accurate, low-range zero reference sensor. Since the pressure is now near zero, the transfer sensor's reading (which would typically be several hundred bar) can be compared directly to the zero reference sensor's reading (only a few bar). The zero reference sensor is highly accurate at this low range because it is never subjected to high ambient pressure. This comparison allows the system to accurately measure the bias (drift) that has accumulated in the high-range transfer sensor. Ambient (A): Returning to normal logging. The low-pressure valve is closed, sealing off the zero reference sensor again to protect it. The pump piston is extended, returning the internal manifold pressure back up to the ambient seabed pressure. The ambient valve is opened, re-exposing the transfer sensor to the external seawater pressure. The instrument is now back in its normal logging mode, and the measured bias from the Zero stage is used in post-processing to correct all the pressure data logged by the transfer sensor since the last calibration cycle, effectively eliminating the sensor drift. More details can be found here .
